keyTakeAways: A steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon snapped during operation, resulting in a fatal crash that killed at least 16 people and injured others.
The cable failed to meet certification standards set by CARRIS, the operator of the funicular, and also did not meet the operator’s own specifications.
The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) identified serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
Maintenance tasks were falsely marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was recorded as 'compliant and accepted' despite not being properly executed.
Eyewitnesses described the crash as a violent, uncontrolled descent, with one man named Bruno describing it as 'like a toy being thrown' from one side of the street to the other.
The preliminary report is not final and a full investigation report will be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A deadly funicular crash in Lisbon, Portugal, in September 2025, resulted in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries when a steel cable snapped, causing one of the funicular cars to derail and crash into a building. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal that the cable failed to meet certification and operational specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular's operator. Additionally, maintenance records show falsified entries, with tasks marked as completed despite being unperformed, and the maintenance plan falsely labeled as 'compliant and accepted.' Eyewitnesses, including a man named Bruno, described the descent as chaotic and uncontrollable. While the interim findings are preliminary, they highlight significant systemic failures in safety protocols, maintenance, and oversight, raising concerns about public transportation safety in historic urban infrastructure.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
